theory_metadata.source_work: Rediscovering the Social Group: A Self-Categorization Theory
theory_metadata.theoretical_tradition: Social psychology, social identity theory, group processes
theory_metadata.original_purpose: Explain how and when people define themselves in terms of group memberships and how this affects perception, judgment, and behavior

telos.primary_purpose: Predict when individuals will categorize themselves as group members rather than unique individuals and explain resulting cognitive and behavioral changes
secondary_purposes: Explain stereotype formation and application processes
Predict group polarization and conformity phenomena
Analyze leadership emergence and influence processes
Understand intergroup differentiation and conflict dynamics
telos.theoretical_scope: Individual-level self-concept and group identification processes
telos.domain_applicability: Group communications, identity statements, collective behavior descriptions, leadership appeals, intergroup contexts

classification.tier_justification: Explains group behavior through self-categorization processes and predicts when group vs. individual identity will be salient

self_categories.definition: Cognitive representations of the self at different levels of abstraction

social_categories.definition: Cognitive classifications of people into groups based on perceived similarities

comparative_context.definition: Frame of reference that determines which categories become salient

prototypes.definition: Idealized representations of category members that maximize intragroup similarity and intergroup difference

categorization_principles.functional_antagonism: Personal and social identity are functionally antagonistic - activation of one inhibits the other
categorization_principles.meta_contrast_principle: Category salience determined by ratio of intergroup to intragroup differences
categorization_principles.comparative_fit: Categories become salient when they best fit the comparative context
categorization_principles.normative_fit: Categories become salient when content matches expectations
categorization_principles.accessibility: Recently used or chronically important categories are more likely to become salient

comparative_fit.definition: How well category boundaries match actual similarities and differences
comparative_fit.measurement: Ratio of between-group to within-group differences on relevant dimensions

normative_fit.definition: How well category content matches stereotypical expectations
normative_fit.measurement: Degree of match between observed and expected category characteristics

accessibility.definition: Readiness of categories to be activated in memory

behavioral_consequences.depersonalization: Perception of self and others as interchangeable group members rather than unique individuals
behavioral_consequences.stereotype_activation: Automatic application of group-based expectations and judgments
behavioral_consequences.group_polarization: Shift toward more extreme positions consistent with perceived group norms
behavioral_consequences.conformity_pressure: Motivation to align attitudes and behaviors with group prototype
behavioral_consequences.intergroup_differentiation: Emphasis on differences between groups and similarities within groups

step_1_applicability_assessment.description: Evaluate text suitability for self-categorization analysis

criteria.group_categorization_present: Clear use of group categories and social classifications
criteria.identity_salience_indicators: Evidence of group vs. individual identity activation
criteria.comparative_context_clear: Identifiable frame of reference for category comparisons
criteria.prototype_content_available: Descriptions of typical or ideal group members

step_1_applicability_assessment.scoring: 0.0-1.0 scale based on presence and clarity of self-categorization elements

step_2_category_identification.description: Identify all social categories and self-categories present in the text
category_extraction: Extract explicit group labels and classifications
Identify implicit social categories from context
Determine category boundaries and membership criteria
Map category hierarchies and abstraction levels
self_category_analysis: Identify speaker's self-categorization (personal vs. social identity)
Determine which social identities are activated

step_3_comparative_context_analysis.description: Identify the frame of reference that determines category salience
context_analysis: Assess which categories are made mutually exclusive
Evaluate context factors affecting category accessibility

step_4_prototype_extraction.description: Identify prototypical representations of social categories
prototype_analysis: Extract descriptions of typical or ideal group members
Identify attributes that define category membership

step_5_salience_assessment.description: Evaluate factors determining category salience and accessibility
salience_analysis: Assess comparative fit (intergroup vs. intragroup differences)
Evaluate normative fit (match with stereotypical expectations)

step_1_categorization_process_analysis.description: Analyze how self-categorization processes operate in the text
process_analysis: Identify shifts between personal and social identity
Assess functional antagonism between identity levels
Evaluate meta-contrast effects on category salience
Analyze category accessibility and activation patterns

step_2_depersonalization_assessment.description: Evaluate extent of depersonalization and group-based perception
depersonalization_analysis: Assess degree of group-based vs. individual-based perception
Evaluate interchangeability assumptions about group members

step_3_group_behavior_prediction.description: Predict group-relevant attitudes and behaviors based on categorization
prediction_analysis: Predict conformity to perceived group norms

step_4_identity_salience_dynamics.description: Analyze factors that would increase or decrease category salience
dynamics_analysis: Identify conditions favoring personal vs. social identity
Assess contextual factors affecting category accessibility
Predict identity salience changes across contexts

internal_consistency.category_definition_coherence: Social categories are clearly defined with consistent boundaries
internal_consistency.prototype_content_validity: Prototype descriptions match category membership criteria
internal_consistency.salience_assessment_logic: Category salience evaluations follow comparative fit and accessibility principles
internal_consistency.identity_level_distinction: Clear separation between personal, social, and human identity levels

theoretical_fidelity.functional_antagonism_application: Analysis recognizes competition between personal and social identity
theoretical_fidelity.meta_contrast_principle_usage: Category salience determined by intergroup/intragroup difference ratios
theoretical_fidelity.fit_accessibility_integration: Both comparative/normative fit and accessibility factors considered
theoretical_fidelity.depersonalization_focus: Analysis emphasizes group-based rather than individual-based processes

empirical_validation.category_identification_accuracy: Valid extraction of social categories and boundaries from text
empirical_validation.salience_factor_assessment: Accurate evaluation of comparative fit, normative fit, and accessibility
empirical_validation.behavioral_consequence_prediction: Valid prediction of group-relevant attitudes and behaviors

predictive_validation.identity_salience_prediction: Accurate prediction of when group vs. individual identity will be prominent
predictive_validation.stereotype_activation_forecasting: Valid prediction of when and which stereotypes will be applied
predictive_validation.group_behavior_prediction: Accurate prediction of conformity, polarization, and differentiation effects
predictive_validation.contextual_sensitivity_assessment: Valid prediction of how context changes affect categorization
